PerformanceNavigationTiming.summary: The PerformanceNavigationTiming interface provides methods and properties to store and retrieve metrics regarding the browser's document navigation events. For example, this interface can be used to determine how much time it takes to load or unload a document.

remarks.para: Only the current document is included in the performance timeline, so there is only one PerformanceNavigationTiming object in the performance timeline. It inherits all of the properties and methods of and .
The following diagram shows all of the timestamp properties defined in PerformanceNavigationTiming.

para.see: Timestamp diagram listing timestamps in the order in which they are recorded for the fetching of a document

PerformanceNavigationTimingActivationSta.summary: CAUTION Non-standard The activationStart read-only property represents the time between when a document starts prerendering and when it is activated.

remarks.para:
-Speculation Rules API
-Speculative loading

PerformanceNavigationTimingActivationSta.value: A representing the duration between document prerendering start and activation in milliseconds.The value is 0 if the page has not prerendered or is still prerendering.

PerformanceNavigationTimingCriticalCHRes.summary: NOTE Experimental A website can indicate that a particular Client Hint is critical to the page by including it in a Critical-CH HTTP response header (as well as the Accept-CH HTTP request header which is needed for all client hints whether critical or not). Doing so will trigger a connection restart if the hint listed in the Critical-CH HTTP response header could have been, but wasn't, included in the HTTP request initially sent. If the browser does not support that client hint, it is ignored and no connection restart occurs.

remarks.para: The criticalCHRestart read-only property represents the time at which the connection restart occurred.

-Client hints
-User-Agent Client Hints API
-Improving user privacy and developer experience with User-Agent Client Hints (developer.chrome.com)
-Accept-CH
-Critical-CH

PerformanceNavigationTimingCriticalCHRes.value: A representing the number of milliseconds elapsed since when the connection restart occurred in milliseconds.If the value is 0 the connection was not restarted.

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomComplete.summary: The domComplete read-only property returns a representing the time immediately before the user agent sets the document's readyState to "complete".

remarks.para: See also the complete state of which corresponds to this property and refers to the state in which the document and all sub-resources have finished loading. The state also indicates that the event is about to fire.

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomComplete.value: A representing the time immediately before the user agent sets the document's readyState to "complete".

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomContentLoa.summary: The domContentLoadedEventEnd read-only property returns a representing the time immediately after the current document's DOMContentLoaded event handler completes.

remarks.para: Typically frameworks and libraries wait for the DOMContentLoaded event before starting to run their code. We can use the domContentLoadedEventEnd and the domContentLoadedEventStart properties to calculate how long this takes to run.
-DOMContentLoaded

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomContentLoa.value: A representing the time immediately after the current document's DOMContentLoaded event handler completes.

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomContentLoa.summary: The domContentLoadedEventStart read-only property returns a representing the time immediately before the current document's DOMContentLoaded event handler starts.

remarks.para: Typically frameworks and libraries wait for the DOMContentLoaded event before starting to run their code. We can use the domContentLoadedEventStart and the domContentLoadedEventEnd properties to calculate how long this takes to run.
-DOMContentLoaded

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomContentLoa.value: A representing the time immediately before the current document's DOMContentLoaded event handler starts.

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomInteractiv.summary: The domInteractive read-only property returns a representing the time immediately before the user agent sets the document's readyState to "interactive".

blockquote.para: This property is not Time to interactive (TTI). This property refers to the time when DOM construction is finished and interaction to it from JavaScript is possible. See also the interactive state of which corresponds to this property.

remarks.para: Measuring DOM processing time may not be consequential unless your site has a very large HTML source to a construct a Document Object Model from.
If there is no parser-blocking JavaScript then the DOMContentLoaded event (see domContentLoadedEventStart for the timestamp) will fire immediately after domInteractive.

PerformanceNavigationTimingDomInteractiv.value: A representing the time immediately before the user agent sets the document's readyState to "interactive".

PerformanceNavigationTimingLoadEventEnd.summary: The loadEventEnd read-only property returns a representing the time immediately after the current document's load event handler completes.

remarks.para: -load event

PerformanceNavigationTimingLoadEventEnd.value: A representing the time immediately after the current document's load event handler completes.

PerformanceNavigationTimingLoadEventStar.summary: The loadEventStart read-only property returns a representing the time immediately before the current document's load event handler starts.

remarks.para: -load event

PerformanceNavigationTimingLoadEventStar.value: A representing the time immediately before the current document's load event handler starts.

PerformanceNavigationTimingNotRestoredRe.summary: NOTE Experimental The notRestoredReasons read-only property of the interface returns a object providing report data on reasons why the current document was blocked from using the back/forward cache ({{Glossary("bfcache")}}) on navigation.

remarks.para:
-Monitoring bfcache blocking reasons
-

PerformanceNavigationTimingNotRestoredRe.value:
When the associated PerformanceNavigationTiming object represents a history navigation, notRestoredReasons returns a object.When the PerformanceNavigationTiming object does not represent a history navigation, notRestoredReasons will return null. This is useful for determining whether bfcache is not relevant to a particular navigation (as opposed to notRestoredReasons not being supported, in which case it would return undefined).
NOTEnotRestoredReasons may return null despite the navigation type being reported as a back/forward navigation. These circumstances include duplicating a back/forward navigation in a new tab and restoring a back/forward navigation tab after a browser restart. In such cases, some browsers copy the navigation type from the original tab, but as these are not actually back/forward navigations, notRestoredReasons returns null.

PerformanceNavigationTimingRedirectCount.summary: The redirectCount read-only property returns a number representing the number of redirects since the last non-redirect navigation in the current browsing context.

remarks.para: The higher the number of redirects on a page, the longer the page load time. To improve the performance of your web page, avoid multiple redirects.
The and properties can be used to measure redirection time. Note that they will return 0 for cross-origin redirects.
Note that client side redirects, such as <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="0; url=https://example.com/"> are not considered here.

PerformanceNavigationTimingRedirectCount.value: The redirectCount property can have the following values:

PerformanceNavigationTimingToJSON.summary: The toJSON() method of the interface is a {{Glossary("Serialization","serializer")}}; it returns a JSON representation of the object.
PerformanceNavigationTimingToJSON.returns: A {{jsxref("JSON")}} object that is the serialization of the object.

PerformanceNavigationTimingType.summary: The type read-only property returns the type of navigation.

remarks.para: You can use this property to categorize your navigation timing data as each of these types will have different performance characteristics. Users going back and forth might experience a faster site than users performing navigation for the first time or submitting forms, etc.

For example, if your site provides new content frequently, you might want to refresh that content using Fetch or similar and avoid users having to hit reload for the entire page all the time. The "reload" type can help you find pages that are reloaded frequently.

PerformanceNavigationTimingType.value: The type property can have the following values:

PerformanceNavigationTimingUnloadEventEn.summary: The unloadEventEnd read-only property returns a representing the time immediately after the previous document's unload event handler completes.

remarks.para: -unload event

PerformanceNavigationTimingUnloadEventEn.value: The unloadEventEnd property can have the following values:

PerformanceNavigationTimingUnloadEventSt.summary: The unloadEventStart read-only property returns a representing the time immediately before the previous document's unload event handler starts.

remarks.para: -unload event

PerformanceNavigationTimingUnloadEventSt.value: The unloadEventStart property can have the following values:
